awd_titl_txt: Differential Geometric Problems in Mathematical Relativity
awd_abstract_narration:
The remarkable detection, announced by LIGO in 2016, of gravitational waves generated by distant black holes has once again affirmed the extraordinary power of Einstein's General Theory of Relativity. General relativity is a geometric theory of gravity; in this theory the effects of gravity are due to the curvature of the universe. The gravitational field and other fields, black holes and related objects, may be described and analyzed using geometric methods.  In very general terms, this project is concerned with the study of certain features of gravity of current scientific interest from this geometric point of view, utilizing the tools of Riemannian geometry, a mathematical theory of space, and Lorentzian geometry, a mathematical theory of spacetime. These theories provide a method for studying the relationship among three fundamental aspects of the spacetime universe: curvature (i.e., the bending of space or spacetime), topology (i.e., the global shape and complexity of space or spacetime) and causal structure (i.e., the large scale behavior of light rays and light cones).
 
An initial data set in a spacetime consists of a smooth spacelike hypersurface, its induced metric and second fundamental form.  The principal investigator (PI) will continue his investigations concerning asyptotically flat initial data sets with horizons.  Such initial data sets model isolated gravitating systems with black holes.  In this context the PI, with various collaborators, has established results on 'topological censorship' at the initial data level, for initial data sets in three and higher dimensions.  These results establish, under natural physical assumptions, restrictions on the geometry and topology of the spatial domain of outer communication in black hole spacetimes. They rest in large measure on the rather recently developed theory of marginally outer trapped surfaces (MOTSs).  These are objects of considerable interest.   On the one hand they play an important role in the theory of black holes, and on the other, they may be viewed as natural spacetime analogues of minimal surfaces in Riemannian geometry.  Although MOTS are not in general variational objects, they nevertheless turn out to have properties remarkably similar to minimal surfaces.   The work of the PI, and related results, lead to many interesting open problems that the PI will investigate, including problems concerning the topology of MOTSs and the spatial domain of outer communication, as well as problems concerning MOTS existence and rigidity phenomena, both in the compact and noncompact case.  Topological issues will benefit from a deeper understanding of the relationship between MOTSs and so-called immersed MOTSs.  The PI will also work on some problems pertaining to `time-symmetric'  (i.e., totally geodesic) initial data sets.  The PI will implement a strategy for proving a positive mass theorem for asymptotically hyperbolic (AH) manifolds, in the spirit of the Schoen-Yau positive mass proof in the asymptotically Euclidean case. The research has the potential to close a gap in previous positive mass proofs in the AH case.  A further aim in this direction would then be to try to use this method to obtain a proof of the Horowitz-Myers conjecture concerning the AdS soliton.  The PI will also continue on-going projects involving photon spheres and spacetime rigidity problems.

por.por_cntn:
Einstein's General Theory of Relativity is a 'geometric' theory of gravity.  The field equations of General Relativity (known as the Einstein equations) describe how our spacetime universe curves in the presence of matter, and it is this curvature that is responsible for the effects of gravity. As the famous physicist John Wheeler put it, "Matter tells spacetime how to curve and spacetime tells matter how to move".  The field of Mathematical General Relativity,  to which this project belongs, explores the consequences of the Einstein equations in spacetime models that can represent a single star or the entire universe.  Black holes (which can result from the gravitational collapse of a star after exhausting its nuclear fuel) are certainly one of the most remarkable predictions of General Relativity.   In the  1970's, Stephen Hawking presented his work on the theoretical and mathematical foundations of black holes.  Since then significant progress has been made in our understanding of black holes.  Our current understanding of gravitational collapse is consistent with the remarkable detection of gravitational waves announced by LIGO in 2016, and predicted by Einstein 100 years earlier. 

A number of the findings of this project stem from concepts and properties considered in Hawking's foundational work on black holes, as well as in his work in cosmology, which is concerned with the study of the universe in its entirety.   

In this project, the PI established a strengthened `rigidity' property of black holes that extends his earlier work on the topology (shape complexity) of black holes with R. Schoen. The latter work generalized Hawking's black hole topology theorem to higher dimensional spacetimes (of the sort that commonly appear in string theory).  Positive mass theorems play an important role in general relativity, as they deepen our understanding of the concept of mass, linear momentum and angular momentum in the theory. Motivated by certain problems related to the spacetime positive mass theorem, the PI, together with M. Eichmair and A. Mendes, obtained a `global version' of the rigidity property mentioned above.  This has now been used to establish, in joint work with P. Chrusciel, a positive mass theorem for asymptotically hyperbolic spaces that allows for black hole type boundaries.  Such spaces arise naturally in string theory, in particular, in the AdS/CFT correspondence.   

The PI's work with R. Schoen on the topology of black holes raised a number of questions that have been studied up to the present.  Extending earlier work of M. Khuri and E. Woolgar, the PI, together with these two researchers, obtained new results on the topology of stationary (steady state) near extremal (near zero temperature) black holes in 4+1 dimensions.  To obtain these results it was necessary to establish a new Bakry-Emery version of the Cheeger-Gromoll `almost splitting theorem'.   In a separate work, the PI, with Khuri and Woolgar, were also able to use this almost splitting theorem to investigate the topology of the entire universe, assuming it is of finite extent.  A separate result established physical (and measurable) conditions under which the universe is of finite extent.  

In further work in the cosmological setting, the PI, together with E. Ling, obtained a generalization of Hawking's cosmological 'big bang' singularity theorem to the case of a positive cosmological constant, consistent with what is observed in the universe today. While Hawking's theorem in general does not hold in cosmological spacetimes with positive cosmological constant, by applying the Penrose singularity theorem and results on the existence of minimal surfaces, which imply the existence `trapped surfaces', it is shown that past incompleteness of the universe can fail only for universes with very special topology.    

Other outcomes of this project include work with E. Ling on the existence of constant mean curvature spacelike hypersurfaces in cosmological spacetimes,  work with C. Cederbaum, which extends the classical results on the uniqueness of the Schwarzschild spacetime to the case of static spacetimes containing 'photon surfaces' (spacetime surfaces ruled by light rays, such as the photon sphere in Schwarzschild spacetime), and work with L. Andersson, M. Dahl and D. Pollack establishing restrictions on the topology of the region of space (in 3 and higher dimensions) outside of all black holes, consistent with the Principle of Topological Censorship.
